title: Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS)
summary: Sets minimum safety standards in the construction, equipment and operation of merchant ships.
content: The International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) is the most important international maritime treaty. Key chapters: Ch-I (General Provisions), Ch-II-1 (Construction/Stability), Ch-III (Life-saving appliances), Ch-IV (Radiocommunications/GMDSS), Ch-V (Safety of Navigation - AIS/VDR), Ch-IX (ISM Code), Ch-XI-2 (ISPS Code).

title: Prevention of Pollution (MARPOL)
summary: Main convention covering prevention of pollution of the marine environment by ships.
content: MARPOL 73/78 covers: Annex I (Oil), Annex II (Noxious Liquid Substances in Bulk), Annex III (Harmful Substances in Packaged Form), Annex IV (Sewage), Annex V (Garbage), Annex VI (Air Pollution - Sulphur Cap 0.50%, NOx Tiers, EEDI/SEEMP/CII).

title: Standards of Training & Watchkeeping
summary: Qualification standards for masters, officers and watch personnel.
content: Sets qualification standards (CoC) and watchkeeping rules. Key mandates: Minimum rest hours (10 hours in any 24-hour period, 77 hours in any 7-day period). Requires familiarization training, basic safety training, and medical fitness standards.

title: Maritime Labour Convention
summary: The 'Seafarers' Bill of Rights' regarding working and living conditions.
content: Establishes minimum working and living standards. Covers: Minimum age, Medical certification, Qualifications, Seafarers' Employment Agreements (SEA), Wages, Hours of work and rest, Entitlement to leave, Repatriation, Accommodation, Food and catering, Medical care.

title: Hague-Visby Rules
summary: International rules for the carriage of goods by sea (Liability Limits).
content: Updates the Hague Rules. Defines carrier responsibilities (Seaworthiness, Care of Cargo) and immunities (Act of God, Perils of the Sea, Fire). Limits liability to 666.67 SDR per package or 2 SDR per kg of gross weight, whichever is higher.

title: IMSBC Code
summary: International Maritime Solid Bulk Cargoes Code.
content: Mandatory for safe stowage and shipment of solid bulk cargoes. Classifies cargoes: Group A (Liquefiable - TML/FMP required), Group B (Chemical Hazard), Group C (Neither). Requires shippers to provide cargo information prior to loading.

title: Intl. Ship & Port Facility Security Code
summary: Comprehensive set of measures to enhance the security of ships and port facilities.
content: Part of SOLAS Chapter XI-2. Requires ships to have a Ship Security Plan (SSP), Ship Security Officer (SSO), and continuous synopsis record. Sets Security Levels (1, 2, 3) dependent on threat level. Mandatory for all passenger ships and cargo ships >= 500 GT.

title: Ballast Water Management
summary: Standards and procedures for the management and control of ships' ballast water and sediments.
content: Aims to prevent the spread of harmful aquatic organisms and pathogens. Requires ships to have an International Ballast Water Management Certificate (IBWMC), a BWM Plan, and a Ballast Water Record Book. Most ships must now use Treatment Systems (D-2 Standard).

title: Intl. Maritime Dangerous Goods Code
summary: Uniform principles for the transportation of dangerous goods by sea.
content: Mandatory under SOLAS and MARPOL. Covers packing, container traffic and stowage, with particular reference to the segregation of incompatible substances. Classifies dangerous goods into 9 classes (e.g., Class 1 Explosives, Class 3 Flammable Liquids).

title: International Safety Management Code
summary: Standard for the safe management and operation of ships and for pollution prevention.
content: SOLAS Chapter IX. Requires a Safety Management System (SMS) to be established by the Company. Key certificates: Document of Compliance (DOC) for the office, Safety Management Certificate (SMC) for the ship. Designated Person Ashore (DPA) provides link between ship and shore.

title: Hamburg Rules
summary: UN Convention on the Carriage of Goods by Sea (Shipper-friendly).
content: Alternative to Hague-Visby. Holds carrier liable for loss, damage, or delay unless they prove they took all measures to avoid it. Liability limits are higher: 835 SDR per package or 2.5 SDR per kg. Not as widely adopted as Hague-Visby.

title: Rotterdam Rules
summary: Modern convention for contracts of carriage (Door-to-Door).
content: Extends carrier's responsibility period to door-to-door (if agreed). Addresses electronic documentation (e-bills of lading). Liability limit: 875 SDR per package or 3 SDR per kg. Still in the process of ratification by major trading nations.
